snippet: By wiring up the insect-eating plant, scientists found that it counted the electrical impulses that came from trigger hairs on its leafy jaws.
abstract: Study in journal Current Biology concludes carnivorous Venus flytrap plants count number of times trigger hairs in their flytrap mouths are stimulated in order to determine whether insect or just piece of debris has entered; electrical pulses caused by biochemical changes alert plants, with at least two stimuli in under 20 seconds indicating insect, which is then devoured.
lead_paragraph: By wiring up the insect-eating plant, scientists found that it counted the electrical impulses that came from trigger hairs on its leafy jaws.

headline.print_headline: The Venus Flytrap, a Plant That Can Count
headline.main: The Venus Flytrap, a Plant That Can Count
